ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend taking with other profs if you like learning French.
Little outside work, very easy material. Interesting readings.

Solid cap on the French program at Yale. In addition to the semi-daily course packet homework and biweekly exams, there's also a "final speaking project" which is a 5-10 minute presentation about a subject relevant to WWII in France; this presentation was a lot more relaxed and less difficult than I first thought--you will be surprised by how well you can do at L4, which is great. Exams are straightforward (same as L3, at least) and homework is as well. Readings are a mixed bag. You read two novels--one an older, more difficult to read "classic" piece of French literature and the other a newer (and longer, but easier) piece that is about two French Jewish kids in WWII. Other than that, you read a lot of selections from a compendium of stories from the whole French-speaking world called "Diversit." About half of these are pretty interesting and the others are fairly boring. I think overall the reading is about the same mix of good and bad as L3, but there is more overall.
Natural continuation/reinforcement of grammar skills from FREN130 with a focus on some very compelling short stories from the Francophone world.
I would recommend this course but only with Koizim.
